byline.contributor: Katrin Bennhold reported from Paris, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Aurelien Breeden and Laure Fourquet contributed reporting from Paris.
byline.original: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and ERIC SCHMITT

abstract: French government continues to review gaps in surveillance that resulted in Paris terrorist attacks by Said and Cherif Kouachi and Amedy Coulibaly; French intelligence has long been considered among best in world, but Charlie Hebdo attack has caused debate about quality of European intelligence gathering.
lead_paragraph: The nation chose to stop monitoring Saïd and Chérif Kouachi before they struck Charlie Hebdo. But there is no consensus on what lessons to learn.

headline.main: Gaps in France’s Surveillance Are Clear; Solutions Aren’t
headline.print_headline: Gaps in Surveillance Are Clear; Solutions Aren’t

snippet: The nation chose to stop monitoring Saïd and Chérif Kouachi before they struck Charlie Hebdo. But there is no consensus on what lessons to learn.
